qaPairs.question: What is the Dominions Random Number (DRN) used in Dominions 6?
qaPairs.answer: The Dominions Random Number (DRN) is a roll of two six-sided dice (2d6) with an additional rule: if any individual die roll is a "6," one is subtracted, and then that die is re-rolled and added to the result. This open-ended 2d6 roll can occasionally lead to large numbers.

qaPairs.question: How does the "open-ended" 2d6 roll work in the DRN system?
qaPairs.answer: If either of the two dice in the 2d6 roll lands on a 6, one is subtracted from the total, and that die is re-rolled and added to the result. This process repeats if the re-rolled die also lands on a 6, potentially leading to large numbers.

qaPairs.question: Why was the Dominions Random Number (DRN) system created?
qaPairs.answer: The DRN system was created to model the idea that very few things are actually impossible in the world of Dominions. It ensures that events that are very unlikely can still occur, which wouldn't be possible with a non-open-ended roll.

qaPairs.answer: While DRN refers to a roll of two six-sided dice with the open-ended rule, "drn" in lower-case letters refers to situations where only one six-sided die is rolled, but it is still open-ended.
